description:
Happy 1st April! This means that‚Ä¶ Our Virtual Flag Day 2022 is here! (And no, it‚Äôs not an April Fool‚Äôs joke üëª)
 
For the last 70 years, many of you have helped Singapore Children‚Äôs Society make a difference to the lives of our beneficiaries, and we can‚Äôt thank you enough.
Every donation you make will help us reach out to those in need, and enable our professional staff at our service centres islandwide to continue providing care and support to our beneficiaries.
 
Please continue to support our cause & drop an e-token of love this Virtual Flag Day!
Be a part of the reason why their bucket is full of hope today üòä
 
Donate & find out more through the link in our bio: @sgchildrensoc 
 
#flagday2022 #fundraising #charity #givingback #donatetoday

üëÄ Take a peep into #adayinthelife of a youth worker as Ms Izyan from @jyc_at_scs takes us through her day! It was also a special one as our youth members were recording their performances for our recent 1000 Enterprises for Children-in-Need and 1000 Philanthropists Appreciation Event. Opportunities like this engages our youth meaningfully, develops their strengths and builds their self-confidence.
 
Watch till the end for a mini surprise! (Hint: TikTok dances üëØ)
 
#adayinmylife #youthwork #youthworker #sgchildrensoc

Singapore Children‚Äôs Society held the 1000 Enterprises for Children-in-Need (1000E) & 1000 Philanthropists (1000P) Appreciation Event 2022 yesterday at PARKROYAL on Beach Road ‚ú® This event allows us to recognise the generous enterprises & philanthropists who supported the programmes in 2021.
 
It was our honour to have Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security, Mr Teo Chee Hean, who is the Patron for the 1000E and 1000P programmes as our Guest-of-Honour. SM Teo presented certificates to 40 donors who attended the event onsite.
 
We are truly grateful for the support we‚Äôve received in helping us further our mission of bringing relief and happiness to children in need üòä
 
To join the programmes & find out more, visit: 
https://www.1000e.org.sg/ (#linkinbio @sgchildrensoc)
https://www.1000p.org.sg/ (#linkinbio @sgchildrensoc)
 
#fundraising #charity #givingback #donatetoday

Today is World Water Day. To raise awareness about water conservation, our youth beneficiaries from JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society teamed up with senior rowers from SG Dragons to clean up Lower Seletar Reservoir on 16 March. As Dan Wen, one of our beneficiaries who took part in the cleanup, put it : ‚ÄúI had a lot of fun during the kayaking and cleanup‚Ä¶I feel happy to not only enjoy myself during the event but also helping the environment‚Äô. Thanks to the organisers Camelot Singapore and PUB for giving our beneficiaries the chance to be a part of this meaningful event. Read the article through the link in our bio @sgchildrensoc 

#makeeverydropcount #goblue4SG  @pubsingapore @jyc_at_scs

‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm Tinkle Friend! What would you like to talk about today?‚Äù

Do you enjoy chatting with children? Are you able to listen and empathise with others? We are currently recruiting volunteers to man our Tinkle Friend helpline and online chat for primary school children in Singapore! Tinkle Friend volunteers offer a listening ear to children who call in or chat with us online about their issues and concerns.

If you are 21 years old and above and keen to be a Tinkle Friend volunteer, you can find out more and register through the link in our bio @sgchildrensoc

Please contact the Tinkle Friend team at 6276 5077 from Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5.30pm and/or email us at tinklefriend@childrensociety.org.sg if you have any queries about the volunteering opportunity.

We hope to welcome you into our Tinkle Friend family üòä

#tinklefriend #sgvolunteer

It is World Social Work Day today! We invited Ms Tan Bee Joo, Senior Director and Group Lead of Family Services to share more about her 24-year journey with Singapore Children‚Äôs Society.
 
In her starting years, she was involved with casework and counselling for low-income families and had also worked with youth in Project CABIN ‚Äì drop-in centres in secondary schools for students to have a conducive environment to hangout after school hours. She led projects such as the Bully Free programme and Tinkle Friend as she took on a managerial role, and today, she continues to serve vulnerable families and their children in the Yishun community.
 
Swipe to see some of the many memorable moments Bee Joo hold close to her heart üíñ. She also shared her hopes for Children‚Äôs Society as it marks its 70th anniversary this year.
 
From the bottom of our hearts, thank you all social workers for your contribution! #socialworker #worldsocialworkday #sgchildrensoc70

Are you a big fan of Carousell? Since June last year, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society has started to accept donations through the platform!
 
Go check out our account (#linkinbio), where you can make donations easily between $5 to $20. It may seem like a small amount, but it means the world to our beneficiaries and affirms the work we do for our community. ‚ù§Ô∏è Do make a donation while browsing the app today and help Children‚Äôs Society continue to bring hope and smiles to our beneficiaries! #sgchildrensoc70 #giveback

Food insecurity refers to a state where one lacks physical and economic access to sufficient, nutritious food. Being cash-strapped and facing financial constraints, low-income families are more likely to experience food insecurity. 

To better understand their challenges and experiences, we interviewed children and caregivers from low-income families about their food consumption habits. 

Read more about their experiences in our last article, ‚ÄúHow Do Low-Income Families Experience Food Insecurity?‚Äù and learn more about how you can do your part as an individual to support low-income families via the link in our bio.

#researchbites

What do you do when you suspect that child abuse is ongoing? Child abuse has been on the rise in Singapore for the past decade. Members of the community play a crucial role in responding to suspected child abuse to safeguard children. However, the decision to act and intervene is not always an easy one. 

In the second article of our February issue of Research Bites, ‚ÄúThe Decision-making Experiences of Bystander Witnesses to Suspected Child Abuse‚Äù, we look at some of the tensions and dilemmas faced by bystanders to suspected child abuse, and how they decide whether or not to intervene. 

Read more via the link in our bio.

#researchbites

Academic and education-related stressors can be difficult on children, but what about its effects on parents? How do parents experience the challenges that come with trying to support their children in their studies? 

We interviewed parents and professionals working with children to better understand parents‚Äô experiences in relation to their children‚Äôs education. 

Read more about parents‚Äô challenges and concerns in the first article, ‚ÄúParenting as a Balancing Act: Challenges Relating to Involvement in Children‚Äôs Education‚Äù of our February issue of Research Bites via the link in our bio.

#researchbites

ü§î How can you help your child change his bullying behaviour? Hear more from Mr Taufiq Salehoodin, Social Programme Assistant Manager from Student Service @ Children‚Äôs Society.

#tipsfromtheexpert #bullying

Singapore Children‚Äôs Society CEO Ang Boon Min shared about our Society‚Äôs 70th Anniversary milestone on Mediacorp Capital 958 radio station. Besides looking back on our history during the interview, she also shared about how our programmes and services evolved to meet the changing needs of children and youth. We also appealed for ex beneficiaries to contact us and share their precious memories. They can reach us directly via social media or email us at info@childrensociety.org.sg.  Click link in bio to watch the interview.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell anyone, this is our secret,‚Äù is a phrase often used by perpetrators so that they can continue to commit sexual acts with children. Hence it is important to teach children the N.O.T. rules ‚Äì to say No, walk Out, and Tell a trusted adult if they encounter a bad touch or inappropriate action.

Watch this short animation clip with your child and observe how April applies the N.O.T. rules in this unsafe situation.

#bodysafety #KidzLive

‚ÄúIs it too early for preschool children to learn about sexuality?‚Äù ‚Äì this is a question which the team behind our child sexual abuse prevention programme, KidzLive: I Can Protect Myself, commonly hears. It is never too early to start teaching body safety skills, and the key is to engage in age-appropriate conversations and to make use of teachable moments.

Here, we share our body safety infographic series and KidzLive information booklets that can be used as springboards for conversations. Share these resources with a parent, educator, or anyone who might be interested!

Visit the link in our bio for more info about the KidzLive booklets.

#bodysafety #KidzLive

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of stigma and secrecy in talking about child sexual abuse,‚Äù said Ms Lin Xiaoling, Deputy Director of the Research and Advocacy Department at Singapore Children‚Äôs Society. Let's break the stigma and secrecy by overcoming our own barriers and start having a conversation with our children about body safety skills. 

Read more via the link in our bio.

Stay tuned for this week‚Äôs posts as we will be sharing resources that you can use as a springboard for further conversations.

#bodysafety #KidzLive

The digital world is all around us, and it is here to stay. Our children and youth increasingly use and rely on‚ÄØdigital technologies for a variety of reasons, which makes staying safe online more important. 

In this ParenTIPs podcast on Safer Internet Day, we hosted members of Project Techmap from the Singapore Children‚Äôs Forum 2021/22. Hear from our youth participants Daryl, Clarisse, and Ezann as they share about what they do online, what they like about it, as well as some of the issues they confront, including tensions with parents over screen time and usage. They also suggested tips for children and their parents/caregivers to ensure safe, engaging, and positive online experiences. 

Happy Safer Internet Day! 

Tune in to the podcast via the link in our bio.

#parentips #SaferInternetDay #SID2022 #sgchildrenforum

The digital world is all around us, and it is here to stay. Our children and youth increasingly use and rely on‚ÄØdigital technologies for a variety of reasons, which makes staying safe online more important. 

In this ParenTIPs podcast on Safer Internet Day, we hosted members of Project Techmap from the Singapore Children‚Äôs Forum 2021/22. Hear from our youth participants Daryl, Clarisse, and Ezann as they share about what they do online, what they like about it, as well as some of the issues they confront, including tensions with parents over screen time and usage. They also suggested tips for children and their parents/caregivers to ensure safe, engaging, and positive online experiences. 

Happy Safer Internet Day! 

Tune in to the podcast via the link in our bio.

#parentips #SaferInternetDay #SID2022 #sgchildrenforum

Thank you @vasantham_mediacorp for visiting Student Service @ Children‚Äôs Society to have a chat with our Senior Social Worker, Ms Leela Narayana (right) who is part of the Tinkle Friend team. Leela shared about the common issues primary school students have raised when they call Tinkle Friend and the challenges they have faced amidst the pandemic. The episode in Tamil is now available for viewing (link in bio).

A self-funded service of Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, Tinkle Friend is a national toll-free helpline and chatline for all primary school students in Singapore. Tinkle Friend provides support, advice, and information to lonely and distressed children, especially in situations when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable. Trained staff and volunteers supporting the helpline and chatline operations guide children through problem-solving in a non-directive and caring approach.

After 42 years of providing children a safe place to be while their parents worked, Student Care @ Children‚Äôs Society (SCC) in Bukit Merah View will close its doors on 31 December 2021.

The seeds for SCC were sown in the late 1970s when then-Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew expressed concern about ‚Äúlatchkey children‚Äù ‚Äì children who typically wore their house keys around their necks so they could let themselves into their homes after school. These children often returned to empty houses, and fended for themselves until their parents returned from work.

Through the decades, the Student Care service model has evolved with greater emphasis on supporting children from disadvantaged families with school-based student care. This is now available in almost all primary schools. The Ministry of Education is also expanding the After School Engagement programmes for both primary and secondary school students. Within Bukit Merah, many community agencies also provide similar services through their student care centres. This allows us to shift our focus to other needed programmes. We will work with community agencies to explore how we can continue to support the children and young persons living in the area in other ways.

On behalf of all past and present beneficiaries, thank you to the staff and volunteers who have kept the centre going for over four decades, and created fond memories to last a lifetime! ‚ú®

Calling all children and youth under 18: What does mental health mean to you and why is it important? This is an invitation to you to record a short video message (30-60 secs) on mental health. Share your thoughts on the needs and challenges that young people face and what actions you think are needed to address them.
 
Organised by the @un_violenceagainstchildren and @crcasia, your message could be part of a video project with children all around Asia! The final video will be aired to healthcare professionals, civil society organisations and policy-makers around the world, among others.

How can young children fundraise to help other children who are in need? Low Jia Li, Manager and Team Lead from our Community Engagement and Partnerships Team shares in our Tips from the Expert series on how children can make a difference. #tipsfromtheexpert #fundraise

In the last episode, we spoke about school bullying and the impact it can have on children. Our speakers highlighted that children who experience bullying often do not speak up or seek help. Instead, they may try to downplay it or even perform their daily tasks as though it didn't happen. This is a challenge that parents and caregivers, even professionals, commonly face because we may not know when is the best time to step in and if there is even a need for us to do so.

Hear from our Bully-Free team as they share strategies and practical handles on how to support children. In this age of smart phones and rise of social media, they also explore and share some insights into cyberbullying. #bullyfree 

Podcast link in bio.

Singapore Children‚Äôs Society turns 70 in 2022! To celebrate this milestone, we want to hear from you. Tell us how your life as a current or former beneficiary, volunteer or even staff, has been impacted and touched by Children‚Äôs Society. Or contribute artwork for our special Anniversary collaterals. Your art piece can speak of your connection with us. You can DM us, email us at corpcomms@childrensociety.org.sg or find out more info at https://www.childrensociety.org.sg/articles/contribute-towards-our-70th-anniversary-celebrations
Wishing all our Hindu friends and supporters, a Happy Deepavali! May your festival of light celebrations be joyous and safe. ‚ú®

Tomorrow, we celebrate the International day against violence and bullying at school, including cyberbullying. It is commemorated by UNESCO Member States every first Thursday of November each year. Regardless of the learning environment, be it at school or on the virtual realm, a child should feel safe as they grow. 

At Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, we run the Bully-Free programme that aims to build a safe and supportive school culture free from bullying. 

Tune in to the first of a 2-part series on bullying as professional speaking coach Benjamin Loh recounts his school bullying experiences and the negative impact it had on him. He is joined by Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs Bully-Free team, as they share about the types of bullying and how to spot some of the warning signs. #bullyfree 

For more resources: please visit https://bullyfree.sg/
Tune in to https://anchor.fm/sgchildrensoc for current and future episodes of ParenTIPS.

More than 70 volunteers & donors were honoured for their dedicated service and generous support at the Singapore Children‚Äôs Society Awards on Saturday 30 Oct. Held in a hybrid format, the Awards was held for recipients for the years 2020 and 2021, with more than 20 recipients receiving their awards from President Halimah Yacob at the onsite event. The Society's top service accolade, the Ruth Wong Award, was presented to Captain Suresh Menon and Dr Tan Seok Hui, for the year 2020 and 2021 respectively (Dr Tan attended the event virtually). Gartner Advisory (Singapore) Pte Ltd also received our Gopal Haridas Award for being our top donor. We thank all our award recipients for their unwavering support and dedication to Children‚Äôs Society and our beneficiaries.

‚ÄòDo you think anyone deserves to be bullied?‚Äô

üôã ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt think anyone deserves to be bullied as everyone deserves to be happy‚Äô. 

üîä Sound on to hear our children share their thoughts on the topic of bullying #intheirownwords. 

#hearourchildren #childrensday2021 #bullyfreesg #sgchildrensociety

An immediate response is necessary to stop and manage bullying. Hear from our children on how they would react to bullying incidents. 

üîä Sound on to hear them #intheirownwords! 

#hearourchildren #childrensday2021 #bullyfreesg #sgchildrensociety

From the analysis of our Tinkle Friend chats last year, we observed that some children may have been experiencing verbal and relational bullying. 

Everyone can play a part in fostering a Bully-Free environment. We invited children to share their thoughts on this topic. 

üîä Sound on to hear them #intheirownwords on what bullying means to them.

Did you know that 90% of your child‚Äôs brain is developed by the time they are 5 years old‚ùì

KidSTART is a programme that aims to give children a good start in life by providing upstream support to children aged 6 and below. Under @kidstartsingapore, we provide support for child development, coordinate and strengthen holistic services for families where needed, and monitor the developmental progress of children from birth onwards. In addition, we also support eligible families in their child‚Äôs preschool enrolments to better prepare them for subsequent years of formal education.

Here at KidSTART @ Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, we support KidSTART families in Bedok and Geylang Serai with Singaporean children below the age of 6 and earning a household income of below $2,500. If you are pregnant or have a child aged 6 and below, come join us for our first KidSTART Digital Roadshow on Saturday, 18 September, 10.30am to 11.30am to find out how you can make a difference in your child‚Äôs early developmental years! Stand to win attractive prizes by participating in the fun, interactive activities prepared for you and your children! 

Register now for the free Zoom roadshow via link in bio. Registration closes on 15 September, don‚Äôt miss out! üòä

[Calling youth aged 13 to 18] Is it okay to take a path less travelled? ‚õ∞ With the kind of academic expectations society places on us, we're bound to feel the heat. But everyone's journey is different, and that's okay.

So how do we still make sense and meaning of our own path, regardless of what it is? And how do we stick to following our own path?

Hear from our guest speaker Ms Faith Ng, Associate Artistic Director of @checkpointtheatre as she shares her journey of how she started out as a young writer, including the mistakes and discoveries she made along the way, and learn why it's important to hold true to who we are.

Sign up today via the link in bio! This learning session is organised as part of the Singapore Children's Forum 2021/2022.

#sgchildrensociety #sgchildrenforum #studyinginsingapore #pathlesstravelled

[Calling youth aged 13 to 18] As digital natives in today‚Äôs world, the use of digital media is deeply embedded in our lives.

The online world allows us to access useful information, create content, communicate with our friends and family and much more. On the other hand, it is also where we can be exposed to harm.

How can you stay safe and informed as you engage with the digital world? üåè 

Hear from our guest speakers Mr David Ng, a child rights advocate on online safety and digital citizenship and @flagyoureit, Singapore's first movement against online child grooming.

Sign up today via the link in bio! This learning session is organised as part of the Singapore Children‚Äôs Forum 2021/2022.

#sgchildrensociety #sgchildrenforum #digitalworld #stayingsafeonline

Our heartiest congratulations to our Deputy Chairman Prof Ho Lai Yun for being conferred the Public Service Star (Bar) for this year's National Day Awards! Prof Ho started volunteering with Singapore Children's Society in 1988; today he is the Society‚Äôs Deputy Chairman as well as the Chairman of our Research and Advocacy Standing Committee (RASC). 

Under Prof Ho's leadership, RASC is actively engaged in different aspects of work done on the prevention of child abuse and neglect in Singapore. The Singapore Children‚Äôs Society Lecture, inaugurated in 2007 to mark the Society‚Äôs 55th Anniversary Celebrations, was also Prof Ho‚Äôs brainchild. The annual lecture which features an expert speaker on a subject related to children, youth and families, reaches out to professionals working with children and families as well as to the members of the public.

Besides having dedicated more than 30 years to champion for the protection and well-being of children in Singapore, Prof Ho has also been an active volunteer in other aspects of work in Children‚Äôs Society. Sitting on multiple committees, he serves in the Human Resource and Remuneration Committee and the Nominations Committee. He is also the Deputy Chairman of the Crisis Management Committee and the Chairman of the Awards Committee for the Singapore Children‚Äôs Society Awards, which formally recognises volunteers and donors for their dedication and generosity. 

On behalf of all staff and beneficiaries, thank you Prof Ho, for your dedication and contribution!

(Photo taken during the 13th Singapore Children‚Äôs Society Lecture in 2019 where Prof Ho moderated the Q&A session)

Since 1999, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society has conducted two sets of studies on the public's and professionals' perceptions of child abuse and neglect, and how perceptions have changed over time. 

In the second article of our latest issue of Research Bites, "Understanding perceptions of child abuse and neglect in Singapore: Our progress and future directions", we review major child protection milestones in Singapore and discuss the lessons we learnt from the perception studies. 

Read more via the link in our bio!

[Calling youth aged 13 to 18] COVID-19 has impacted us in unprecedented ways. It has lasted more than a year and we can feel the COVID fatigue setting in. How can we then bounce back better? üí™

When Singapore went through Circuit Breaker between April and June 2020 due to COVID-19, major changes such as school closures and parents working from home could have impacted children‚Äôs access to social support. To understand children's experiences during this period, we analysed some Tinkle Friend online chats which is our national chat platform for primary school children. 

Read more about children‚Äôs concerns in the first article, "A friend in need: Children‚Äôs concerns during the COVID-19 pandemic" of our July issue of Research Bites via the link in our bio!

Our guest speakers, Adj A/Prof Daniel Fung, CEO of the Institute of Mental Health and Toh Sze Min, Research Officer from Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, share local research findings about ACES and discuss its impact on children. They describe the potential signs that can alert caregivers and educators that a child is negatively affected by ACES and suggest ways on how adults can respond.

Today we celebrate our fathers and honour the important role they play in our lives. We wish all Dads a Happy Father's Day!

Fathers play an important role in children‚Äôs development and shaping their behaviours. 

In celebration ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äãof Father‚Äôs Day this weekend, we look at how the emotional bond between fathers and their children influence the development of children's social skills. We hope that these tips would help fathers connect better with their children.

With the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, we looked into the influence of COVID-19 on children‚Äôs social support during Circuit Breaker last year.

Based on the data gathered from our Tinkle Friend online chats, we found that some children experienced relationship difficulties with their parents due to blurred work-life boundaries. Some children also had difficulties reaching out to teachers and friends for support.  With recent tighter safe distancing measures and work-from-home as default once again, we draw upon some of the lessons learnt to provide tips on how families can cope better this time.

#COVID-19 #CopingwithCOVID

#casestory
At a young age, Alisah* was separated from her parents due to their incarceration and has been living in Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society since then. Due to the separation, it created some resistance and anxiety in meeting her birth parents when they
were first released from prison. Over time, Alisah built up her trust with them, only to be disappointed when her parents got caught for taking drugs again. 

The adversities caused Alisah difficulties in keeping up with her studies and she developed maladaptive ways to cope with her struggles such as hitting her head against the wall. Despite the unfavourable family circumstances and various health concerns, Alisah showed great tenacity and resilience. With the help of care workers at Sunbeam Place @ Children‚Äôs Society, she managed to cope better and developed good moral values. 

Help us to continue providing beneficiaries like Alisah, a safe and nurturing space to develop and grow. A donation of $50 can help cover the transportation costs for a child. Start impacting lives today (link in bio). 

*Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary

Wishing our Buddhist friends, colleagues and supporters peace, love, and harmony on this Vesak Day. Happy Vesak Day and stay safe!

#casestory‚Å£
From birth, children would have received much care and attention from their parents. However not all children have the opportunity to‚Å£
grow up in a nurturing environment. John* was only 3 when he witnessed the arrest of his parents due to drug offences.‚Å£
‚Å£
As a little boy, he would look forward to the release of his parents hoping to have a complete family. However, his dreams were ‚Å£
short-lived as his parents continued with their addictions, leading to multiple incarcerations. Because of this, John suffered multiple placement breakdowns, moving from living with his family to his relatives, to a shelter for displaced families and finally to Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society.‚Å£
‚Å£
Despite these difficult times, John persevered and remained resilient. His interest and talent in floorball kept him grounded as he focused his energy in it and as a result, was able to apply for the school of his choice via Direct School Admission.‚Å£
‚Å£
With just $90, you can help us to look after one beneficiary, like John for one month by sponsoring his meal costs. This amount might seem small, but it will make a big difference in their lives. Start impacting lives today (link in bio).
‚Å£
*Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary

Research Bites is celebrating our 5th anniversary! To celebrate this milestone, our 10th issue features the theme of children's voices.
 
Our first article, "Which types of social support promote resilience among children from low-income families?" highlights the impact of income-related stressors on child outcomes, and the importance of children‚Äôs perspectives on their social support. Our study advisor, Dr. Quah Saw Han, also shared insights about these findings and how they can help us to better serve children in need. 
 
In our second article, "Respecting children‚Äôs voices: How can practitioners promote child participation?", we explore child participation and provide tips on how we encourage children‚Äôs voices using examples from our services.
 
Our last article, "What can you do if your child experiences academic stress?", shares the common sources of academic stress experienced by children and ways parents can engage children in conversations relating to academic stress.
 
Read our latest issue via the link in our bio!

üéµ You‚Äôre now listening to: Signs üé∂

After a year in making, we present Signs, a song written and produced by our very own youth members from JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society (GIG @ JYC) to raise awareness on the need of seeking help when one experiences early signs of distress.

Through this music video, we hope to help listeners identify signs of distress and remind them that support can be found around them. 

A quick shout-out to Leonard from the @snakeweedstudios  for making this possible through your help with the song‚Äôs recording!

#SignsbySCS #mentalhealth #mentalhealthawareness #sgchildrensociety

Calling all parents! Did you know that Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs), which are potentially traumatic events that happen before the age of 18, can have a long-lasting impact on children's physical and mental well-being? 
 
Safe Circle is a collaboration across seven agencies including the Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, that focuses on community-based mental health services for children and youth. In this second run, we are offering a complimentary workshop on trauma-informed care for parents. 
 
Sign up to learn about what trauma entails, its prevalence in Singapore and how to integrate trauma-informed care into your lives as parents. For more details and to register, please click here: bit.ly/safecircle2021

#traumainformed #traumainformedcare #mentalhealth #safecircle #talksandworkshops #sgchildrensociety

Self-care is a term we hear all the time. But what does self-care mean for parents? In the last of this three-part series on positive parenting, find out why it's okay to be a 'good enough' parent.

Anger is an emotion that everyone experiences. However, coping with anger can be challenging for some children, leading to behavioural outbursts or disruptive behaviours. Moreover, the many changes caused by the ongoing pandemic may pose greater challenges for children to cope with their emotions. It is important that children learn and find ways to manage these strong and intense feelings.

Join our Storm Riders programme over the June school holidays to find out how children can manage their emotions in a safe and healthy manner. Sign up now at bit.ly/StormRiders2021 (link in bio). Do also share this post with others whom you think may benefit from it!

#anger #angermanagement #angerissues #emotionalhealth #emotion #regulation

At the young age of 2, Shan* was admitted to Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society as her parents were unable to care for her due to drug addiction and depression issues. Her mother passed on when she was only 7 years old and Shan stayed on at Sunbeam Place @ Children‚Äôs Society. 

Shan remained positive and disciplined in her school work, working hard as she aims to be an accountant in the future. She scored good grades in her preliminary examinations and strives to enrol in an accounting course in a local polytechnic. 

At Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society, we provide a temporary home for children and youth who have been abused or severely neglected to live in. They too, have the right to having their basic needs met just like their age peers. This includes going to school as usual and having pocket money to buy their meals.

With just $45, you‚Äôll help us to look after one beneficiary, like Shan for one month by paying towards her school pocket money. This amount might seem small, but it will make a big difference in their lives. Click the link in our bio to start impacting lives today.

*Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary

#shopforacause #lazada #giveback #nonprofit

What needs to be in place for positive parenting to happen? Parents need to be attuned to their children's needs, and this means building up a trusting and secure relationship from young. Helping children understand the consequences of their actions on others is also an effective parenting strategy to learn. Hear about these and more in part two of this three-part series on positive parenting. 

Tune in at https://anchor.fm/sgchildrensoc

#parenting #parentingsg #parentips

Safe Circle is a collaboration across seven agencies including the Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, that focuses on community-based mental health services for children and youth. In this second run, we are offering a complimentary workshop on trauma-informed care for parents.

We start off the first of our ParenTIPS podcast exploring the issue of positive parenting. In the first of this three-part series, we look at corporal punishment as a disciplinary approach, and understand what science tells us about the effectiveness and impact of it. Tune in at https://anchor.fm/sgchildrensoc

Today also marks our first physical fundraising event (and a very socially distanced one!) ‚Äì Tee Up for Our Children üèë ‚Äì after one full year of cancelled events. All funds raised through this event will go towards running programmes at one of our service centres, JYC @ Children's Society - a community drop-in centre which focuses on engaging children and youth meaningfully to develop their strengths, build their self-confidence and pre-empt a path of juvenile delinquency. 

As one of our JYC members put it, ‚ÄòIt is really more than just a centre. I can even call it my home after all my experiences here and the sense of belonging I have built in here.‚Äô 

Help us keep our JYC family running for our current and future beneficiaries. Click the link in our bio to donate today!

With easy access to the internet and electronic devices, children get to play, learn, create, and connect. It is important for them to stay safe while navigating the digital world.
 
Start having conversations with your children about how they can stay safe online. Our friends @crcasia have also made a book for children to be e-safe!

www.tinyurl.com/SafeWebForKids

Safe Circle is a collaboration across seven agencies including the Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, that focuses on community-based mental health services for children and youth. 

We are offering a complimentary talk and workshop on trauma-informed care for parents and educators. Learn about what trauma entails, its prevalence in Singapore and even how to integrate trauma-informed care into your work and lives.

For more details and to sign up, please click here: bit.ly/safecircle2021

#traumainformed #traumainformedcare #mentalhealth #safecircle #talksandworkshops #sgchildrensociety

A big thank you to the @playeum team and Coach Mike from Tendencies for organising an interesting and fun activity for the residents of Sunbeam Place @ Children‚Äôs Society! This project is also supported by @temasektrustsg's oscar@sg fund.

Towards the end of last year, our residents gathered for an exciting Art of Speed challenge where they worked together to build a moving vehicle with recyclable materials such as toilet rolls and unused plastic cutlery as well as motors and batteries. Their vehicles were then put to a test to see if they could survive moving through a track that was filled with obstacles.

Through experiment and play, our residents had a lot of fun learning about physics as well as discovering new things about themselves and their friends such as their strengths and weaknesses!

#physics #handsonlearning #experiment #play #oscarsgfund #sunbeamplace #sgchildrensociety

Have you joined the characters, Sam, Dan and Lydia in saving the fictional world of Scribble Town? ‚öìÔ∏è

To raise awareness on the issue of bullying, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society has collaborated with the National Heritage Board to present Scribble Town, an interactive exhibition for children aged between 9 and 12. The exhibition held at the Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall ends this 31 January so make your way down if you have yet to! 

Through the interactive elements at each station, visitors will be prompted to reflect on their own experiences of bullying, whether they have been victims of bullying themselves or have acted in ways that count as bullying. 
 
For more information on bullying, visit www.bullyfree.sg. Together we can create a #bullyfreesg.

#antibullying #SayNotoBullying #exhibition #museum #ilovemuseums #sgchildrensociety

It‚Äôs about THREE weeks to the Lunar New Year. For many of us, this festive period speaks of family reunion. As we look forward to gathering with our families and relatives albeit in smaller groups, there are some families like Madam Tan‚Äôs* who are not able to get together to celebrate this Lunar New Year due to an incarcerated family member. 

Click on the link in our bio to read more about Madam Tan‚Äôs story and support us in our efforts to strengthen families. 

Donate today and embrace the spirit of kindness and giving this Lunar New Year. 

*Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary 

#alittlekindnesslotsofjoy #fundraising #giving

Happy New Year, everyone! üéâ Wishing all an amazing 2021 filled with happiness and joy.

Happy Boxing Day! We hope you are having a great Christmas weekend with your loved ones. 

2020 has not been an easy year for all of us, but you have made it possible for us to support our beneficiaries amidst the pandemic. From the bottom of our hearts ‚ù§Ô∏è, we thank you! 

We are also at the tail end of our #BeOurSanta üéÖ campaign. Grab the chance to make your final contribution in the link in our bio! 

As 2021 approaches, we hope you can continue to support the work we do at Singapore Children‚Äôs Society. Have a smashing last few days of 2020!

The second part of the Choo Choo Train Resource is now launched! In partnership with Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, @british_theatre_playhouse is hosting a campaign called ‚ÄúGive a Child a Book‚Äù where members of the public can purchase a Christmas book produced by the British Theatre Playhouse entitled, ‚ÄòCovi, the little Christmas dinosaur‚Äô for the children cared for by Children‚Äôs Society. This book features a real-life 7-year-old girl, Harmonie-Rose who lost her arms and legs to meningitis when she was just 1 year old. It is their hope (and ours) that reading this book will raise awareness of meningitis and inspire children around the world during these difficult times. On top of that, you may also donate to Singapore Children‚Äôs Society to support the programmes and services that we run for children, youth and families in need. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Join us this Christmas in bringing hope to the children at Singapore Children‚Äôs Society through Covi, the little Christmas Dinosaur! Visit this link to purchase the book or donate to us > bit.ly/giveachildabook

Before @thefort.scs open its doors back in October 2018, youth workers carried out a Community Needs Assessment which included surveying youth in the area to understand more about the facilities and programmes they would like to see in a youth drop-in centre.

The Fort @ Children‚Äôs Society has since been a safe space for youth members to hang out after school hours and engage in activities they enjoy such as cooking, baking, and gaming. Through the various programmes and activities designed to suit the needs of the youth, the Centre also aims to develop the youth‚Äôs strengths in the 5Cs ‚Äì Caring, Character, Competence, Confidence and Connection.

‚û°Ô∏è For more on our reflections behind the setting up of a youth drop-in space and effective engagement with youths, download a copy of ‚ÄòA Guide to Youth Drop-In Centres‚Äô from the link in bio!

#youthcentre #youthwork #youth #dropincentre #resource

Singapore Children‚Äôs Society has launched ‚ÄòA Guide to Youth Drop-In Centres: Reflections from Research and Practice‚Äô to consolidate the research, theories and reflections behind the setting up of a youth drop-in space and effective engagement with youths. This guide is an enhanced version of an early guide released in 2011, which articulates the practice wisdom and research findings behind the operations of a youth drop-in centre. 

‚û°Ô∏è Find out more about the guide and download a complimentary copy from the link in bio!

#youthcentre #youthwork #youth #dropincentre #resource

#Fact: The number of applications for financial assistance has doubled and the funds disbursed under Singapore Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs Casework Fund almost tripled this year compared to last year. 

Our Casework Fund provides financial assistance to needy families so that they can pay for meals, daily necessities, children‚Äôs school expenses etc. Help our beneficiaries by donating to our Virtual Flag Day campaign. All donations raised will go towards the Society‚Äôs Casework Fund and any unused Casework Fund donations will be carried over to 2021 and beyond so that we can continue to extend a lifeline to as many families in need. 

Give from your ‚ù§Ô∏è today, click on the link in our bio!

In the month of October, we celebrate CHILDREN üë´ ‚Äì the future of our nation. Singapore Children‚Äôs Society has been working hard for 68 years to promote the well-being of children. 
 
Did you know that there are children of pre-school age who do not receive the education they need to build a strong foundation in their learning journeys? In this video, our counsellor Joanne tells us why pre-school education is important, and how we reach out to families in need so that their children do not miss out on pre-school education as a result of their circumstances. 

Please donate generously to support our programmes and services, including pre-school outreach, that seek to protect and nurture children and youth of all races and religions‚ù§Ô∏è. 

Visit bit.ly/chiday2020.

Giving persons with depression a safe space to share their thoughts is one way of supporting them. Non-verbal cues can also play an important role in our conversations.

We had previously developed a guide to help children recognise their body warning signs when they feel unsafe. To access this guide, please click here: bit.ly/kidsguidestaysafe

The guide now takes a more interactive form with #SafeSimon. Safe Simon says that it is important for children to know and listen to their body warning signs when they feel unsafe. Our children should grow up safe and happy.

Singapore Children‚Äôs Society is part of the Safe Circle, a collaboration across seven agencies that focuses on community based mental health services for children and youth.

In support of World Mental Health Day 2020, we are pleased to present to you a 1-hour introductory talk that will explore an understanding of trauma, what is trauma-informed care, its principles, and how we can harness trauma-informed practices to support and build resilience in our children and youth who have been through adverse childhood experiences.

Click here to register for one of the seven sessions now: bit.ly/safecircletic

#traumainformed #traumainformedcare #mentalhealth #worldmentalhealthday #worldmentalhealthday2020

How do we talk to our children about sexual abuse? Even though we recognise the need to protect them, we are often unsure how to begin teaching them about unwanted touches and inappropriate actions.

Hear from Ms Lin Xiaoling, Deputy Director of the Advocacy & Research Department, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, on how parents and caregivers can use storytelling to teach children body safety skills.

She will be conducting an online session to introduce ‚ÄòJun and the Octopus‚Äô, a children‚Äôs storybook produced by Children‚Äôs Society which can be used to kickstart meaningful conversations about body safety on Saturday, 12 September from 2pm to 3 pm. Find out more and register at bit.ly/nlbpt

#bodysafety #childsexualabuse

Issue 9 of Research Bites is now available online!

In our previous posts, we shared our Lessons from Evaluating the Choo Choo Train Programme, and sought to answer What is the Role of Fathers in Developing Children‚Äôs Social Skills.

In an age where digital technology is made necessary, children may unintentionally come across sexual images online. How can parents protect children from online sexual images? Our final feature from this issue explores the effectiveness of strategies parents take to protect their children from sexually explicit online materials. We also provide suggestions on how to communicate with children about their bodies and sexual health.

‚û°Ô∏è Read more about what research says about this: bit.ly/RBJUL2020_3 
‚û°Ô∏è Subscribe to future issues of Research Bites: bit.ly/SUBSCRIBERB

Issue 9 of Research Bites is now available online!

During our 13th Singapore Children‚Äôs Society Lecture that was held last year, the late Dr John M. Elliott shared research findings about the role of mothers in children‚Äôs development. Some of our audience were interested to know more about the role of fathers. This article highlights the importance of secure attachment in child development, and provides tips on how fathers can help to develop their child‚Äôs social skills.

‚û°Ô∏è Read more on the role of fathers in developing children‚Äôs social skills: bit.ly/RBJUL2020_2
‚û°Ô∏è Subscribe to future issues of Research Bites: bit.ly/SUBSCRIBERB

Issue 9 of Research Bites is now available online!

In this issue, one of our articles focuses on the lessons from evaluating the Choo Choo Train Programme, which is a programme that teaches moral values to pre-school children using stories and activities. We share some insights on how we determine if our programmes are effective, specifically discussing the steps that we have taken to refine the measures we used to evaluate the Choo Choo Train programme.

‚û°Ô∏è Read more on our takeaways from this evaluation journey: bit.ly/RBJul2020_CCT 
‚û°Ô∏è Subscribe to future issues of Research Bites: bit.ly/SUBSCRIBERB

Close to 50 volunteers spent their Saturday morning learning about the fundamentals of personal data protection and how it impacts us in the social service sector. Titled ‚ÄòData Protection Awareness for Social Services Volunteers‚Äô, the training session was conducted pro-bono by Mr Yuri See, Founder and CEO of Region Management Pte Ltd on 15 August.

The session ended with a Question & Answer segment moderated by Mr Fang Xinwei, who is part of the Volunteer Management team. He was joined by Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs Data Protection Officer Ms Joy Lim and Deputy Data Protection Officer Ms Vivyan Chee as panellists. This online session is part of a series organised by the Volunteer Management team to connect and engage with our volunteers.

This online session is part of a series organised by the Volunteer Management team to connect and engage with our volunteers.

Anger is an emotion that everyone experiences. However, coping with anger can be challenging for some children, leading to behavioural outbursts or disruptive behaviours. Moreover, the many changes caused by the ongoing pandemic may pose greater challenges for children to cope with their emotions.

It is important that children learn and find ways to manage these strong and intense feelings. It will also help them to develop healthy relationships.

Join us in our Storm Riders programme to find out how our children can manage their emotions in a safe and healthy manner.

‚úç Sign up now at bit.ly/StormRiders2020. Do also share this post with others whom you think may benefit from it!

#angermanagement #copingwithemotions #sgchildrensociety

Our heartiest congratulations to our Chairman Mr Koh Choon Hui for being conferred the Distinguished Service Order for this year's National Day Award! Mr Koh, a stalwart of the social service sector for over four decades, had not only expanded Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs reach but also nurtured many social service agencies.

As the Chairman of Singapore Children‚Äôs Society since 1978, Mr Koh has led Children‚Äôs Society to pioneer many new programmes and services to help bring relief and happiness to children, youth and families in need. On behalf of all our beneficiaries, thank you Mr Koh, for your contribution!

‚ÄúChildren are like buds in a garden and should be carefully and lovingly nurtured, as they are the future of the nation and the citizens of tomorrow.‚Äù ‚Äì Jawaharlal Nehru

üì£ We're happy to announce that Jun and the Octopus has been shortlisted as a finalist in the Best Picture Book category of the Singapore Book Awards 2020!

In 2019, we launched Jun and the Octopus, a children's storybook about body safety and sexual abuse prevention. We believe that storybooks serve as a gentle but powerful conversation starter and also they create a safe distance for children to learn about difficult topics.
 
Look out for the next post where the author himself, Mr Goh Eck Kheng shares more on the book creation process! More details to come for the üìΩ Singapore Book Awards 2020 Virtual Live Show that will take place on 13 August 2020 at 4pm.

Over 50 volunteers came together to listen to our colleagues from the Children Outreach @ Children‚Äôs Society speak about how they could learn to connect with children and engage their caregivers two Saturdays ago. Senior Counsellor Ms Serene Jit Kaur and Counsellor Ms Sharon Eng were the trainers for our second online volunteer training session for the year titled ‚ÄòHow to Connect with Children and Caregivers‚Äô. The volunteers learned that they should pay attention to the child‚Äôs mood and behaviour, and be present when engaging with the child. They were also taught strategies to manage parents or caregivers.

The session ended with a Question & Answer segment moderated by Mr Fang Xinwei, who is part of the Volunteer Management team. He was joined by Ms Joy Lim, Director of Children Outreach @ Children‚Äôs Society as a panellist. This online session is part of a series organised by the Volunteer Management team to connect and engage with our volunteers.

Many of our beneficiaries whom we have come across in the last few months are struggling with their day-to-day expenses as their employers are trying to keep their businesses afloat due to the ongoing #COVID19 situation. Ms Ann Hui Peng, Director of Student Service @ Children‚Äôs Society, spoke to Channel 8 regarding the rise in the number of calls and chats our Tinkle Friend service has received since the #COVID19 #CircuitBreaker measures have been set in place.

Some of the issues that the children have shared with #TinkleFriend include being worried about their families‚Äô financial situation as their family members may have lost their jobs and unhappiness due to difficulties in adjusting to #HomeBasedLearning.

Catch the interview at tinyurl.com/8world-tinklefriend

Some of Singapore Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs staff members spoke to @zaobaosg regarding the rise in number of children seeking help and advice from Tinkle Friend. Ms Ann Hui Peng, Director, Student Service @ Children‚Äôs Society noted that more children are inclined to use online chat as compared to phone calls when they talk to Tinkle Friend. Ms Xing Yating, Counsellor, Student Service @ Children‚Äôs Society shared that the issues these children share about include their examination results and relationships with their peers. She noted that there has been an increase of callers sharing issues they may face during home-based learning such as internet connectivity issues and the absence of an adult assisting them with online research. Ms Lin Xiaoling, Deputy Director, Advocacy and Research Department advised parents to take note of children‚Äôs emotions during this period as they may feel unsettled due to the changes to their routines. Read more here: tinyurl.com/zaobao-tinklefriend

As the #COVID19 pandemic rages, lives and routines are disrupted as we try to get used to the "new normal". Do you know our children are having these big feelings too?

If your child needs a listening ear, Tinkle Friend will be here. Your child can call Tinkle Friend helpline at 1800 2744 788 from Mondays to Fridays, 2.30pm to 5pm. Tinkle Friend online chat service is available at www.tinklefriend.sg from Mondays to Thursdays, 2.30pm to 7pm, and on Fridays, from 2.30pm to 5pm.

If you need any resources on how caregivers can address the anxiety that children are facing, please visit tinyurl.com/resources-covid19

Mr Chee Thow Wei Liat, Assistant Director/Head, VOX @ Children‚Äôs Society, spoke to Mediacorp Channel 8 on the impact of COVID-19 on the youth-at-risk. As the centre currently limits the number of youth dropping in due to the COVID-19 situation, he noted that some youth will loiter around public areas such as carparks and void decks. He is concerned that these youth may end up mixing with friends whom may influence them to take drugs or play truant. The Centre is currently using social media platforms to continue their engagement with youth.

Catch the interview at tinyurl.com/covid19vox and follow @vox.44c on Instagram to find out more!

Parenting resources commonly regard the idea of parental warmth as an important part of a parent-child relationship. But does parental warmth equate parental concern? In this video, Prof Elliott unpacks the difference between the two, and uncovers a distinct trait of Asian and Western parents.

This is part two of a three-part series containing the highlights of our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture that was delivered by Dr John M. Elliott on 12 October last year. Dr Elliott passed away on 13 December 2019. He was an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children, and retired as the Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore. Dr Elliott was a long-standing volunteer with Children‚Äôs Society, and served as the Chairman of its Research Committee for close to 20 years.

Read the full lecture transcript: tinyurl.com/13thSCSLectureTranscript

Your children must have heard about the COVID-19 virus and some of them may be feeling anxious or fearful. Do show them our Tinkle Friend* banner and remind them to practise good personal hygiene. They should wear a surgical mask only if they feel unwell and have respiratory symptoms like a cough or a runny nose. *The Tinkle Friend service is manned by trained volunteers and our staff members who provide support, advice, and information to lonely and distressed children, especially in situations when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable.

Every parent wants to raise their children well. They seek tips in different resources, ranging from online parenting articles to parenting books. Yet, many of these parenting resources are from the West, and some may even carry conflicting advice. How can parents decide which is the best way to raise their child?

This is part one of a three-part series containing the highlights of our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture that was delivered by Dr John M. Elliott on 12 October last year. Dr Elliott passed away on 13 December 2019. He was an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children, and retired as the Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore. Dr Elliott was a long-standing volunteer with Children‚Äôs Society, and served as the Chairman of its Research Committee for close to 20 years.

Read the full lecture transcript: tinyurl.com/13thSCSLectureTranscript

#casestory 
Being pregnant is not easy at all. It gets tougher when you have no income, your husband is incarcerated, and you are constantly on the move with no proper roof over your head. You have another child to feed too, but she ran away from home after failing PSLE. That was what Mdm Sara* experienced. 
At her wits' end, she turned to Yishun Family Service @ Children‚Äôs Society where our social worker assisted with her finances and secured a HDB rental flat for her family. 
Mdm Sara would not have pulled through the difficult time without our social worker‚Äôs support. Feeling hopeful for the future, Mdm Sara said: ‚ÄúI have achieved more than what I expected. Thank you, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society.‚Äù *Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary.

Every child needs a listening ear. If you would like to play a part in supporting children in need, sign up to be a Tinkle Friend volunteer at www.childrensociety.org.sg/volunteer-join.

Tinkle Friend is a national toll-free helpline (1800 2744 788) and online chat (www.tinklefriend.sg) for all primary-school-aged children in Singapore. Tinkle Friend provides support, advice, and information to lonely and distressed children, especially in situations when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable.

Being an upstander in a bullying episode is akin to being a hero: a hero that will stand up against bullies. When an upstander sees or hears someone being bullied, they act immediately to provide help and support to the victim.

Since this is the start of a school year, some of you might want to start to promote a Bully-Free learning environment in your school. Swipe left to find out more on how you can be an upstander!

For more information, check out our website at www.bullyfree.sg

#bullyfreesg #childrensociety #antibullying

Being an upstander in a bullying episode is akin to being a hero: a hero that will stand up against bullies. When an upstander sees or hears someone being bullied, they act immediately to provide help and support to the victim.

Since this is the start of a school year, some of you might want to start to promote a Bully-Free learning environment in your school. Swipe left to find out more on how you can be an upstander!

For more information, check out our website at www.bullyfree.sg

"Christmas is not as much about opening our presents as opening our hearts.‚Äù - Janice Maeditere 
As we celebrate Christmas today, let‚Äôs open our hearts and minds and think about giving to the less fortunate. Have a Merry Christmas with your family and friends!

Living in a cramped rental flat while sustaining on a diet of instant noodles and canned food, the Tans‚Äô* everyday life is a common reality for many of our beneficiaries, who fall into financial distress in many ways.

While you are doing your Christmas shopping, we humbly ask that you keep the children, youth and families of Singapore Children‚Äôs Society in your thoughts as there are many families like the Tans who need your help to get back on their feet. 
Donate and help change lives at www.1000p.org.sg/get-involved *Names have been changed to protect the beneficiaries‚Äô identities.

Our youth beneficiaries from JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society played a part in organising a bonding day for tutors and tutees under Project T, a programme under the Youth Executive Committee of Jurong Spring Community Club as part of YouthGIG 2019.

The bonding day included a trip to the Trick Eye Museum where they took many interactive pictures together followed by a hands-on session back at the centre where they used air clay to mould into bird figurines. Lunch was an eventful event as they got to create their own Thai salad.

Mr Desmond Lee, Minister for Social and Family Development & Second Minister for National Development as well as Member of Parliament for the Jurong GRC also visited the youth at the centre and interacted with them.

YouthGIG is an annual event where youth from JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society help to organise, plan and execute a project to give back to the community.

At the 4th Singapore Children‚Äôs Forum this morning themed ‚ÄúWhy is it sometimes not fair?‚Äù, we delved into the world of 25 children and youth who shared their perception on what unfairness and inequality looks like from their lenses.

Attendees were invited to first catch a film that was specially produced for this forum entitled ‚ÄúINequality‚Äù, before joining in a discussion with five distinguished guest panellists. Thank you Assoc Prof @muhammadfaishalibrahim for joining us today. We hope you had a good morning of insightful conversations like we did!

Our youth delegate and adult mentor have spent an engaging and fulfilling past three days at the Asian Children‚Äôs Summit.

They participated in learning sessions and workshops on various thematic issues: children in the digital environment; climate change and the right to a healthy environment; children on the move and violence against children.

This morning, the Summit culminated in a dialogue with adults. The youth delegates presented their recommendations to representatives from the United Nations, ASEAN bodies, government officials and NGOs. This not only allowed them to raise awareness of issues and contribute to improved knowledge but ensured they can meaningfully participate in discussions and decisions that impact them.
 #TheAsiaIwant #ChildRightsAt30 #CRC30

As this year marks the 30th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), there are celebrations all over the world to mark this occasion.

Our youth delegate and adult mentor from JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society are currently in Bangkok, Thailand to participate in the Asian Children‚Äôs Summit from 26 to 29 November 2019. They will be meeting other children and policy makers to discuss key issues that will impact their future including climate change and the digital environment.

Here are some pictures of the pre-summit study sessions with our other youths and snippets from Day 1 of the conference. Stay tuned for more! #TheAsiaIwant #ChildRightsAt30 #CRC30

They will be meeting other children and policy makers to discuss key issues that will impact their future including climate change and the digital environment.

Here are some pictures of the pre-summit study sessions with our other youths and snippets from Day 1 of the conference. Stay tuned for more! #TheAsiaIwant #ChildRightsAt30 #CRC30

Is it possible to spend only $2.63 a day for all your meals? Our social workers embarked on this journey and took on the #livebelowtheline challenge for five days.

Now, it‚Äôs your turn! We invite you and your friends to join the challenge to experience being on a shoestring budget.

Tag a friend whom you want to do this challenge with, and share your journey with us by tagging us using #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

As the #livebelowtheline challenge draws to a close, we are reminded of how this is an everyday reality for some. There may not be a visible end to their challenge.

A single mother we support shares that she manages this reality by being grateful. She shares that without gratitude, one will never have enough no matter how much you have. In fact, this is the refrain many of our clients share. We have much respect for them as gratitude does not come naturally in scarcity.

This has been an exercise of empathy. As social workers, it has also provided us a glimpse into the struggles our beneficiaries experience. We dare not proclaim that we fully understand, but the five-day experience has taught us a whole lot of lessons. We are curious to know how this journey has impacted you. Let us know if you wish to give this a shot, as we would like to hear from you! #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

Greetings from all of us at Singapore Children‚Äôs Society! Here‚Äôs wishing all our Hindu friends and supporters, a Happy Deepavali!

It was the GCE ‚ÄòN‚Äô Level examination period when we were on the #livebelowtheline challenge. A single mother who came to our centre shared that she had no money left after paying for funeral expenses. All she could afford was instant noodles for her son and her own meals till she heads back to work the following week.

This is inequality that is invisible, as the youth would have to sit through national examinations, which may inevitability affect his future schooling or job prospects, with innutritious food had there not been help. He faces many challenges beyond himself, challenges often not measured by standardised tests. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

The lovely matriarch of a family of six managing on $1,600 of monthly salary informs that a family dinner would set her back $50 - $100 because she would have to ‚Äúchip in‚Äù. She would make excuses to her sisters and brothers to avoid attending these gatherings because she simply couldn‚Äôt afford to. There is a sense of being alienated even from your own family, as she often had to say ‚Äúno‚Äù. How does poverty affect socialisation and relationship building for the poor? We often feel excluded when we are unable to join colleagues and peers for meals, movies and gatherings. With the high costs of living in Singapore, recreational activities can be very expensive for middle-income families. What‚Äôs more for the low-income? Many of our beneficiaries tell us that they avoid going to the malls because ‚Äúout of sight is out of mind‚Äù. Read on to find out our struggles as we stave off hunger pangs due to our limited food options in our #livebelowtheline challenge. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

Read on to find out our struggles as we stave off hunger pangs due to our limited food options in our #livebelowtheline challenge. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

The lovely matriarch of a family of six managing on $1,600 of monthly salary informs that a family dinner would set her back $50 - $100 because she would have to ‚Äúchip in‚Äù. She would make excuses to her sisters and brothers to avoid attending these gatherings because she simply couldn‚Äôt afford to. There is a sense of being alienated even from your own family, as she often had to say ‚Äúno‚Äù. How does poverty affect socialisation and relationship building for the poor? We often feel excluded when we are unable to join colleagues and peers for meals, movies and gatherings. #casestory ‚ÄúI remembered an ex-beneficiary in his 50s who worked as a security guard. He would be tasked to work overtime whenever his colleagues were absent. He was happy to work another 10 -12 hours shift as this would mean extra income for his family of five. However, such last-minute arrangement would also mean that he would have to skip his dinner on those nights and go hungry till he reaches home the next morning after his shift. I never asked if there was a fridge or microwave oven at his workplace‚Ä¶‚Äù Many of our low-income beneficiary take up laborious jobs which require more energy but are they eating enough to sustain themselves? #livebelowtheline challenge #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

Our beneficiaries can fall into financial distress in many ways. Businesses fail, sole breadwinners fall sick or pass away and jobs are lost. These events are shocking, often without warning. Quality of life dips fast and the hope of returning to normal life can be distant. The adjustment can be emotionally difficult for these beneficiaries. Kids share that they are worried and afraid when they see the banks removing the television, or when they would need to use their ez-link cards to pay for meals. There are others that face loss and grief when a caretaker is no longer with them. It is a physical, social and psychological adjustment.

Read on to find out how we adjusted our mental, physical and emotional states as we undertake the #livebelowtheline challenge.

#livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

The #livebelowtheline challenge has taught us first-hand how mentally draining shopping on a shoestring budget can be. A tight budget is an everyday reality for some of our beneficiaries. A family of six we know reports their grocery budget to be $600 a month. That comes down to $3.33 per person a day, or $0.70 over our challenge budget. This means that the family often has to choose between paying for utilities or food.

We‚Äôve begun having deeper conversations with our beneficiaries about their food budgets. ‚ÄúHow do you do it? That‚Äôs a tight budget! What do you buy?‚Äù, we would ask. Eventually they share they do spend a little over what they usually report (hence arrears in utilities) but they dare not report a higher number when asking for assistance. They share that sometimes they are embarrassed or worried about a reporting a higher number when are asked why they ‚Äòoverspend‚Äô. We cannot help but wonder. How we can have deeper conversations with our beneficiaries about these topics in a safe, non-judgemental way? #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

Volunteers do not necessarily have the time; they just have the heart. To thank our volunteers for their invaluable contribution, we invited them to our annual Tribute to Volunteers event, where they mingled with fellow volunteers and staff members of Singapore Children‚Äôs Society while they enjoyed a sumptuous buffet brunch, followed by a movie screening.

We would like to say a BIG thank you to all our volunteers, and we hope to see you again next year! üòä

17 October marks the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty. In 2015, the World Bank updated the international poverty line to be at US$1.90 PPP per day, and 736 million people in the world survive solely on that. To raise awareness, The Global Poverty Project @thegpp and The Oaktree Foundation @oaktreeau launched the #livebelowtheline challenge in 2010.

With this in mind, five social workers from Yishun Family Service @ Children‚Äôs Society took on the #livebelowtheline challenge to show our support to this initiative. It also gave them an opportunity to experience how some of the low-income families that we serve feel when they are on a shoestring budget. While Singapore does not have a poverty line, they have learnt so much from jumping on the #livebelowtheline bandwagon. Each of them relied solely on S$2.63* a day, over a period of five days for their meals.

Follow this space as we document the journey of our social workers on this challenge! If this is your jam (pun intended), swipe left to check out the rules of the challenge and feel free to TAG A FRIEND in the comments section below to jio them #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty *Based on the conversion rate for the day for US$1.90.

#SingaporeChildrensForum2019

Our guest speaker, Dr John M. Elliott, spoke about ‚ÄòParenting: Does one size fit all?‚Äô at our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture at the Singapore Management University‚Äôs Mochtar Riady Auditorium this morning.

He discussed about the potential areas where there might be grounds to hesitate in accepting the standard textbook view of best practices in parenting. The lecture ended with a key message from Dr Elliott - Parents are their own best experts to guide their children. We hope you have had an insightful session like we did. See you next year!

Dr Elliott, who retired as Associate Professor from the National University of Singapore‚Äôs Department of Psychology in 2018, is an active volunteer with Children‚Äôs Society‚Äôs Research Committee over the last three decades.

#ParenTIPS

We know that playing with our children is an effective way to build closer bonds with them.

The findings from our Infancy Study (https://tinyurl.com/SCSInfancyStudy) have also shown that children with closer bonds to their mothers had better social-emotional development as they grow up.

How can you better engage your child in play? Here are some ideas from the Department of Child Development at KK Women‚Äôs and Children‚Äôs Hospital!

Thank you @afccsg for having us! We were delighted to be part of a #afcc2019 panel discussion which dealt with difficult topics in children's literature such as child sexual abuse, childhood cancer, and depression.

To promote our book, Jun and the Octopus, we also conducted a workshop on using reading resources and storytelling to equip young children with body safety skills. We then had a "speed dating" session with educators to share more about the book, and how it can be used to empower children with body safety skills.

Grab your copy of Jun and the Octopus for $18 (before GST) at selected bookstores* or at our Bishan Office located at 9 Bishan Place #05-02 Junction 8 Office Tower Singapore 579837 today! :) *Stores include Books Kinokuniya, Huggs-Epigram Coffee Bookshop, and Woods in the Books

Our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture speaker, Dr John M. Elliott, was interviewed by Lianhe Zaobao for his views on parenting.

Despite there being numerous parenting perspectives, Dr Elliott feels that parents should not simply subscribe to any one school of thought or be overly hung up on the labels of "east" and "west", slogans or teachings. Read the full Lianhe Zaobao interview at https://www.zaobao.com.sg/news/fukan/family/story20190916-989404

We are less than a month away from our 13th Lecture! 
It will be held on 12 October 2019, at SMU Administration Building, Mochtar Riady Auditorium from 10am to 12pm.

Are there best practices in parenting? How do parenting practices differ across Asian and Western cultures?

Dr John M. Elliott will be answering these questions and more at the 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture, held on 12 October 2019, at SMU. 
Dr Elliott is an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children. He was an Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore and he retired last year. He is also a long-standing volunteer with Singapore Children‚Äôs Society.

Check out the link in our bio to register your interest!

We were pleasantly surprised and touched when Ms Meriam George, who came all the way from the United Kingdom, gave a generous donation of $1,000 and a handwritten note to support us and the work that we do.

An advocate for children's education, Ms George was inspired by her mother who was a dedicated teacher for four decades and an author of a children's book. ‚ÄúThis donation is made in loving memory of my beloved mother, Mrs No√´lle George, who was a teacher for four decades and had taught the world to sing in perfect harmony,‚Äù said Ms George.

Thank you, Ms George, for your kind words, thoughts and gesture. Let us all continue to work together to bring relief and happiness to children, youth and families in need!

VOX @ Children‚Äôs Society, @vox.44c is one of the four youth drop-in centres under Singapore Children‚Äôs Society.

Holding true to the values of Caring, Character, Competence, Confidence and Connection, our youths from VOX Caf√© collaborated with guides from @dialogue.sg to serve beneficiaries from Filos Community Services.

Even though it was the youths‚Äô first time working with their visually-impaired friends, they managed to communicate effectively and delivered a memorable lunch experience for the beneficiaries.
Singapore Children‚Äôs Society would like to wish our country a Happy 54th Birthday! May we continue to grow in happiness and harmony while living in this little dot of ours :)

‚ÄúI am a single mother of 5 young children aged 1 to 11. It has been very tough for me being the only breadwinner of the family while caring for 5 younger children. I struggled to make ends meet for my children and hence approached Yishun Family Service @ Children's Society for help in 2017. 
My social worker Ms Kate Ofiaza helped me a lot. She has always been there to listen to my problems. With her help, I have also received food rations and school pocket money fund for my children. I have also benefited from the counselling sessions to work on my emotions whenever I have problems. I am really thankful to Ms Kate for her support all this while. She encourages me to be strong and helps to build up my self-confidence. I have become a happier and successful single mom for my children.‚Äù -Ms Noraiin, beneficiary from Yishun Family Service @ Children‚Äôs Society

Do you know of any child who does not attend pre-school because of family difficulties? ‚Å£
‚Å£
Each year, Singapore Children‚Äôs Society reaches out to children who are not registered in a pre-school centre yet and we support these families in enrolling their children to kick-start their educational journey. Follow our social worker Poh Ling, on her pre-school outreach visits as she knocks on doors to reach these households.

Anger is one letter short of danger, and no one is more aware of that than 13-year-old Michael*.‚Å£
‚Å£
When Michael first walked into RoundBox @ Children‚Äôs Society, his explosive temperament led his head first into heated arguments with his peers. Through a journey of engagement and psychotherapeutic interventions, our social workers helped him develop various skills and methods for emotional management.‚Å£
‚Å£
Gradually, Michael developed patience, and went on to challenge himself in other programmes such as the music band. Some of his achievements include performing for President Halimah Yacob as the lead vocalist of the RoundBox band.‚Å£
‚Å£
This Youth Day, we rejoice in the dreams, passions and talents of all youth, regardless of who they are.‚Å£
‚Å£
Help us bring out the potential of tomorrow‚Äôs leaders and innovators when you support Singapore Children‚Äôs Society. Would you like to be a part of this change? https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved‚Å£
‚Å£
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary‚Äôs identity.

Singapore Children's Society conducted a research study together with KK Women's and Children's Hospital from 2007 to 2014 on caregiving arrangements for children in Singapore. We found that the type of main caregiver and the number of times the main caregiver changed had no influence on the child's temperament, attachment, or development. However, we found that babies with a closer bond with their mothers had better social-emotional skills at three years old.

For more details on these findings, please view the July issue of Research Bites at https://tinyurl.com/ResearchBitesJul2019 or read the newly published monograph at https://tinyurl.com/SCSInfancyStudy

#ParenTIPS by Singapore Children‚Äôs Society is a topical parenting series on trends and research concerning children and youth. Through this series, we hope that parents and caregivers can pick up useful ideas and information on how to support their children's well-being and help them thrive.
