Do you know that there is a small percentage of children entering Primary One each year without any form of pre-school education? Pre-school education lays the academic foundation for a child‚Äôs formal education.‚Å£
‚Å£
This is one of the days where our social worker Ms Chloe Aw, from Children Outreach @ Children‚Äôs Society, would follow-up on leads of families who have not registered their children in a pre-school yet, under our Pre-school Outreach programme. Working closely with Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA), our social workers would visit these families to enquire about their children‚Äôs pre-school status and ensure that they receive the necessary assistance for a pre-school placement.

We are excited to announce that our storybook ‚ÄòJun and the Octopus‚Äô was officially launched at @woodsinthebooks yesterday! The storybook was created to empower children with body safety skills to prevent sexual abuse. Our child beneficiaries from Student Care @ Children‚Äôs Society spent a meaningful afternoon listening to the author, Mr Goh Eck Kheng, who read them the book. 
For those interested in getting a copy, ‚ÄòJun and the Octopus‚Äô is for sale at $18 (before GST) in selected book stores, including @kinokuniya_singapore , Huggs-Epigram Coffee Bookshop, and @woodsinthebooks

Despite the bad weather conditions, the mood of students and teachers from Bukit Batok Secondary School were not dampened at all!‚Å£
‚Å£
In line with their annual Sports Day, #BBSS conducted a #fundraising walk - ‚ÄúNo Shoe Day‚Äù, at Clementi Stadium on 26 April 2019 to raise funds for Singapore Children‚Äôs Society! As the name suggests, both students and teachers removed their shoes and went through obstacles such as acupressure mats while donating to the various collection boxes carried by student fundraisers. This event is one of the many holistic activities that the school engages, to #giveback to the community.‚Å£
‚Å£
We are grateful for the support and heartwarming responses from the enthusiastic students and teachers of #BBSS! If you or your school are interested in organising fundraising events for Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, drop us an email at frdda@childrenssociety.org.sg

Are you aware of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)? Our government submits a report to the United Nations every four to five years on our progress in advancing child rights. Watch the above clips to learn about the UNCRC, and how it is relevant to Singapore and to us. 
#ParenTIPS by Singapore Children‚Äôs Society is a topical parenting series on trends and research concerning children and youth. Through this series, we hope that parents and caregivers can pick up useful ideas and information on how to support their children's well-being and help them thrive.

Are you aware of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)? Our government submits a report to the United Nations every four to five years on our progress in advancing child rights. Watch the above clips to learn about the UNCRC, and how it is relevant to Singapore and to us. 
#ParenTIPS by Singapore Children‚Äôs Society is a topical parenting series on trends and research concerning children and youth. Through this series, we hope that parents and caregivers can pick up useful ideas and information on how to support their children's well-being and help them thrive.

#casestudy‚Å£
Mdm Ang* felt the financial strain of having to provide for her two school-going sons after her husband, who was formerly the breadwinner for the family, lost his mobility through a terrible fall. She was alone in her efforts to secure their basic needs while she battled with her own health issues and excruciating pain to take on a labour-intensive job to pay the bills.‚Å£
‚Å£
Thankfully, she found help and advice through the social workers from Yishun Family Service @ Children‚Äôs Society. Through the Centre‚Äôs assistance, Mdm Ang received financial assistance to support her children, and worked closely with our counsellors at Yishun Family Service @ Children‚Äôs Society to alleviate her stress.‚Å£
‚Å£
Why not lend a helping hand to all the strong and brave mummies out there this Mother‚Äôs Day? #mothersday #gratitude ‚Å£
‚Å£
Donate now. https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved‚Å£

#CaseStory‚Å£
It was a tumultuous time for Mr Joe*, a single father without a supportive family network, who only had the love from his children.‚Å£
‚Å£
Mr Joe made a wrong decision to borrow heavily from the loan sharks or illegal moneylenders, who hounded and left him scrambling to find a safe refuge for his children when he could not repay his debts. At wit‚Äôs end, Mr Joe sought help from Singapore Children‚Äôs Society. His children were admitted to Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society temporarily, and were protected from the harassment of the loan sharks while Mr Joe tried to clear his outstanding debts. Our staff members at Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society focused on caring for the children and worked closely with their school teachers and counsellor.‚Å£
‚Å£
On Good Friday, give an act of love by donating to support children, youth and families in need. Help them now >> https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved‚Å£

#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc works closely with the youth, their families and support systems to rehabilitate and encourage youth towards a crime-free and prosocial lifestyle?‚Å£
‚Å£
Every Tuesday at the Youth Court, our team of social service practitioners screen complaints from parents who are considering pursing a Beyond Parental Control (BPC) order against their child. They will hear the parents' complaints and provide them with necessary information to aid them in their decision making. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Thus far, most cases involve running away from home, smoking and other undesirable activities. If you wish to find out more about the programme, drop us an email at bpc@childrensociety.org.sg

No one should have to choose between death and financial hardship. ‚Å£
‚Å£
This #WorldHealthDay, help us ensure more children, youth, and families in need receive all the support they need to emerge triumph from a medical crisis.‚Å£
‚Å£
When you donate to Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, you are helping our beneficiaries get the attention and care they require. Our social workers work extensively with the community to help them apply for financial assistance and other subsidies, so they can cope with living expenses surrounding a medical emergency.‚Å£
‚Å£
Healthcare is a basic human right. #HealthForAll Help us to help our beneficiaries >> https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved‚Å£

We are happy to have Assoc Prof @muhammadfaishalibrahim, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Social and Family Development & Ministry of Education, launch our 29th Project CABIN ‚Äì Chillbox at Meridian Secondary School this morning.

Started in 1994, Project CABIN is a secondary school-based drop-in facility which encourages the development of character and life skills. CABINs provide a positive and conducive environment for youth after school hours which allows our youth workers to reach out to youth more effectively as students spend the bulk of their time in school. Besides organising fun-filled activities, the youth workers also conduct life skills workshops and training courses, as well as provide emotional support for students in need.

As a self-funded charity organisation, we have to raise funds to support the many programmes and services that we run for our beneficiaries. It takes women from every level of the society to create a balanced environment that fosters growth for all. With opportunities presented in the society, they make informed decisions that impact not only themselves, but their children too. Education plays a big part here.‚Å£
‚Å£
Mrs Tan* was a housewife dependent on her husband. However she divorced him as he was abusive and had to raise her seven children single-handedly. As she did not receive much education, she had trouble looking for a job to raise her children. At wit‚Äôs end, Mrs Tan turned to Yishun Family Service @ Children's Society for help.‚Å£
‚Å£
Thankfully, the social workers at the Centre helped her to apply for subsidies to support her children's education. They also equipped her with parenting and financial literacy skills. Since the Society‚Äôs inception, the programmes and services have evolved over time to support more children via avenues such as parenting help for single mothers, sexual abuse awareness and more.‚Å£
‚Å£
Support the work that we do by liking this post today! #IWD2019 #womensday #casestory‚Å£
‚Å£

#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc has a drop-in centre for both children and youth in the west? JYC @ Children‚Äôs Society reaches out to beneficiaries in two different age groups: DEN @ JYC reaches out to children aged 9 to 12 while GIG @ JYC reaches out to youth aged 13 to 18.‚Å£
‚Å£
Our social workers and counsellors engage daily with the youth, building up trust and rapport between them. This helps them open up and share with us their challenges and difficulties they are facing. Through this engagement process, our staff are then able to provide the necessary intervention to them.‚Å£
‚Å£
Sometimes, all it takes is a little patience and time to enter the world of our children, growing with them :)

Chinese New Year is a time where families come together and celebrate the festivities. However, not all children get to experience this.‚Å£
‚Å£
6-year-old Tim* is a resident of Sunbeam Place @ Children‚Äôs Society. He comes from a single-parent family and his mother had returned to her home country to look after another family member. While he remained hopeful that his mother would return one day, he knew deep down that it would not happen so soon. Meanwhile, our social workers at the residential home worked hard to ensure that he does not miss out on education and a proper childhood.‚Å£
‚Å£
Help us, to help children like Tim to receive the love that they‚Äôve always yearned for. Gift an Ang Bao this Chinese New Year so we can continue to care for more children alike.‚Å£
‚Å£
You can help by coming onboard our 1000 Philanthropists programme. Find out more:  www.1000p.org.sg‚Å£
‚Å£
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary's identity.

Taking care of a young child can feel a little overwhelming at times. Our series of parenting guides provides bite-sized information for parents and caregivers on child development milestones, and helpful tips on how to cope with challenging situations. The guides are available at $3 per copy. To purchase a copy, please email us at info@childrensociety.org.sg

#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc runs a national toll-free helpline for primary school children who need a listening ear? ‚Å£‚Å£
If you know of any lonely and distressed children who need to talk to someone, please encourage them to call our helpline (1800 2744 788) or chat with us online at www.tinklefriend.sg !

If you are available in the weekday afternoons, do sign up with us as a volunteer facilitator for our Choo Choo Train programme where you will have the opportunity to conduct activities such as storytelling for our children. To sign up, please click www.childrensociety.org.sg/volunteer-join

Care and attention are vital for development of a child‚Äôs growth. Sometimes, children can be neglected due to parents‚Äô busy work schedule, or simply lacking the means to raise a child.‚Å£
‚Å£
Student Care @ Children‚Äôs Society provides an after school care service for primary school children from low-income, single-parent and/or distressed families who are left at home without adult supervision. It is located within the Henderson neighbourhood and conducts programmes such as Choo Choo Train which aims to instil good character values through interactive games and activities for our children.‚Å£
‚Å£
To date, we have 12 service centres across the island offering programmes and services for children, youth and families in need.

#CaseStory‚Å£
7-year-old Nina* and her younger siblings were often left to their own devices since young. Her father was retrenched and her mother suffered from depression. Thankfully, Nina and her siblings were referred to Student Care @ Children‚Äôs Society, where they received after school care in a nurturing environment.‚Å£
‚Å£
After she has graduated from the Centre, she returned as a volunteer to give back to our Society in hopes of impacting the lives of other children, like how our social workers have impacted hers.‚Å£
‚Å£
It warms our hearts to see children such as Nina, who wants to carry on the spirit of love. This motivates us to do even better at our craft. #givingback‚Å£
‚Å£
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary‚Äôs identity.‚Å£
*Photo credit: Pexels

Our guest speaker Assoc Prof Teo You Yenn, Associate Professor and Head of Sociology at Nanyang Technological University, spoke about Growing up in an Unequal Society this morning at our 12th Singapore Children's Society Lecture at the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre. She discussed the importance of situating the experiences of children and their families in the broader social context.

Our guest speaker Assoc Prof Teo You Yenn, Associate Professor and Head of Sociology at Nanyang Technological University, spoke about Growing up in an Unequal Society this morning at our 12th Singapore Children's Society Lecture at the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre. She discussed the importance of situating the experiences of children and their families in the broader social context.

Welcome back to our #CSCturns10 series! In this fourth post, we have gathered 10 tips to express love for your child, referenced from Gary Chapman and Dr Ross Campbell's "The 5 Love Languages of Children". It is important to note that these should be done unconditionally i.e. not as a reward. Stay tuned for our last two posts as we explore 10 tips for safe online usage for children and 10 things children want adults to know!

#singaporechildrensociety #sgchildrensoc #child #children #parenting #childrenwellbeing #emotionalwellbeing #socialwellbeing #psychologicalwellbeing #5lovelanguages #5lovelanguagesofchildren

Have you ever wondered how it is like to be a banker, policeman or even a postman? "While bullying and its impacts often tend to manifest itself overtly, the emotional and mental consequences are far more severe and lasting. Therefore, bullying should be snipped in the bud as early as possible,‚Äù said V Janani, a year 3 global studies major from National University of Singapore after attending a Bully-Free sharing session recently.

To find out more, please visit www.bullyfree.sg. You can also follow us on @scs.bullyfree.sg

Are you embarrassed to talk to your child about sexuality? You are not alone! Many parents also have concerns about teaching their children body safety skills. Here we address the five common concerns that parents face. You'll find that it's not that difficult to start the conversation with your child today.
This is the second of our #teachbodysafety series. Refer to our bio for our first series. Look out for our final series next Thursday!

Child sexual abuse is not the easiest topic to discuss with our children, perhaps because we don‚Äôt know where to start or how much to teach. The team behind KidzLive, our child sexual abuse prevention programme, is here to share some tips!

Over the next few weeks, we will be addressing common concerns parents have about teaching body safety skills, and highlighting the body safety messages we should relate to our children. Watch this space! In the meantime, find out more from our KidzLive booklet with our link in bio! #teachbodysafety

Watch this space! In the meantime, find out more from our KidzLive booklet with our link in bio! #teachbodysafety

65th Anniversary #Throwback: Do you know, our bubbly blue friend Tinkle Friend has turned 33? Tinkle Friend Helpline (1800 2744 788), a national toll-free helpline for primary school children, was first introduced to children who needed a listening ear in November 1984. In 2014, we started providing Tinkle Friend Online Chat service (www.tinklefriend.com) to children as we evolved with technology. Manned by trained staff and volunteers, both services provide support, advice and information to lonely and distressed children especially when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable. 
Beaten by her parents and bullied by her elder brother, nine-year-old Jenny* felt alone and unloved. She turned to the web, and found comfort in Tinkle Friend, who was willing to listen and give her support and advice. Jenny was eventually referred to her school counsellor, and was grateful for the help rendered. 
There may be many more Jennys out there who need our help. Help us today so that we can change someone‚Äôs tomorrow. Give now: http://bit.ly/2u2GeM3. #Caringforthefuture *Name has been changed to protect the identity of the child. #children #charity #makeadifference #donate

65th Anniversary #Throwback: More than 200 volunteers participated in our Flag Day three weeks ago. This year, our Flag Day was held at ERC Institute SG, where individuals, students and the wider community converged to garner donations to support our cause. 
A team of superheroes also rallied and canvassed for our children in need at Dhoby Ghaut. 
Ms Goh Jiayi, one of our volunteers from Singapore Polytechnic Civil Defence Lionhearters Club, said: ‚ÄúMy most memorable experience is when we passed by a small construction site and asked if the foreign workers would like to donate and help the children in need, they all reached into their pockets, smiled and donated without any hesitation.‚Äù She added: ‚ÄúThis experience has changed my perspective of doing good. I believe that it is not easy for them to earn a living and support their families, but they were willing to help others who are in need.‚Äù Thank you all for making a differenceÔºÅ‚ù§Ô∏è #CaringfortheFuture #makeadifference

The Mid-Autumn Festival carries special meaning as a day for family reunions. It brings joy, love and warmth to families. 
Not every child has the privilege of a proper education and childhood. Under the care of our social workers, children in need are able to receive after school care services and proper education. 
This Mid-Autumn Festival, warm the hearts of our children, spread the love and help build a brighter future for our children by making a small donation today. http://bit.ly/1rWy9fW. #MakeADifference #children #donate #Caringforthefuture

Check out the photo taken by our budding photographer and @roundboxcentre youth, Md Shahrul Nizam. His photo was unveiled during the official launch of My Toa Payoh, Our Stories by MP Mr Chee Hong Tat. Said Shahrul, "I like this photograph because it shows how beautiful Toa Payoh night view can be. From the top of the newest building in the neighbourhood, you can really see almost everything of Toa Payoh, buildings of old and new, and tall and short." What better way to increase your child‚Äôs motivation towards education than through playing games, making new friends and engaging in fun activities? 
This September, come join us at our camp to help your child see the relevance of education in their daily lives and their future aspirations. 
The camp gives children aged 7 to 8 the opportunity to bond with new friends and learn in a creative environment. A trip to Kidzania Singapore is included too. 
Details as follows: 
Date:  Wednesday and Thursday, 6 and 7 September
Time:  9.30am ‚Äì 4.30pm (Day 1)  9.30am ‚Äì 5.30pm (Day 2)
Venue:  Singapore Children‚Äôs Society, Children Service Centre
Cost: $20 (inclusive of an outing to Kidzania Singapore) 
Sign up now!

My Toa Payoh Our Stories, is a RoundBox @ Singapore Children‚Äôs Society community-based initiative supported by HDB that aims to allow the youth to be able to showcase Toa Payoh the way they see it. From 12 August to 28 December 2017, nine selected photographs taken by our RoundBox youth will be put up on display around Toa Payoh, forming an exhibition trail where audiences can embark to not only discover the photographs, but also one of the oldest estates in Singapore. The project will be officially launched by MP Mr Chee Hong Tat on 12 August 2017, 9.30am at the open field next to Toa Payoh Market as part of Toa Payoh West CC‚Äôs National Day celebrations. Come spend your Saturday morning with us and celebrate the start of the exhibition as well as our Nation‚Äôs Birthday! For more information, follow @OURTOAPAYOHSTORIES on Instagram now! #RoundBox #YouthSG #MTPOS #SGPhotography #Singapore #ToaPayoh

Want to know how to better manage your relationship with your child? 
1. Try to set aside time on a regular basis to do something fun with your child
2. Never give an order, request or command without being able to enforce it at the time
3. Be consistent in the rewards and punishments to your child 
Stay tuned for more tips coming up next Friday!

How do your children feel about themselves?

Our colleagues from Talks and Workshops Programmes Centre have recently imparted tips to the students of Yishun Secondary School, on how to feel good about themselves:

1. Give yourself 3 compliments in a day!
2. List 3 things in your day which made you happy!
3. Get active in a sport!
4. Surround yourself with people who appreciate you for who you are!
5. Tell someone if you need help!

What are you doing on the last day of 2015? Why not end the year with a good deed?

Our social worker Kate Ofiaza, from Family Service Centre (Yishun) has recently helped a family regain financial independence, after the family encountered difficulties making ends meet. Having approached the Centre for help, Kate rendered emotional support and ad-hoc food rations for Alinah‚Äôs family, equipped Alinah with problem solving and stress management skills, strategised a plan for clearing her debts, motivated her to provide emotional support to her husband, linked Alinah with job fairs and provided school pocket money fund for her daughter. After receiving help and being re-employed in December last year, Alinah‚Äôs family has now regained financial independence, and is able to manage their finances more effectively.

Kudos to Kate for extending her help! 
#singaporechildrenssociety #familyservicecentreyishun #lastdayof2015

Peer influence and peer pressure can be both positive and negative. Some commonly seen negative peer pressure include grouping together to ostracise particular classmates or going after the latest gadgets in order to feel belonged to a group. On the other hand, positive peer pressure can include influencing the child to study together or encouraging the child to help the less fortunate by participating in voluntary work. 
Share with us how you think parents can support their children in dealing with negative peer pressure!

More than 30 parents of My First Skool (Jurong West) mastered the art of rewarding their children through a Positive Parenting Talk.

The Convalescent Home was one of the first major projects of Singapore Children's Society. Opened in 1956, the half-way home ensured children received proper diet and care until they put on sufficient weight and grew strong enough to go home. 
This Children's Day, continue to support our mission of bringing relief and happiness to children in need. 
Visit www.childrensociety.org.sg for more details!
